Bacterial Leaf Spot.Cause: Bacterial infection (often Xanthomonas spp.) attacking leaves and shoots of grapevines under warm-humid conditions.
Bacterial Leaf Spot.Symptoms: Small yellowish or water-soaked spots on leaves, which enlarge into brown lesions often with a yellow halo; may cause leaf drop or shoot die-back.
Precautions: Use certified disease-free planting material.
Ensure canopy ventilation and avoid prolonged leaf wetness.
Sanitise pruning tools and remove infected plant material.

Chemical: Apply copper-based bactericide sprays shortly after symptom onset.
Alternate contact and systemic bactericides to avoid resistance.
Organic: Use neem oil or plant-derived bactericidal extracts as foliar preventive sprays.
Practice strict field sanitation and remove fallen infected leaves.

Black Rot.Cause: Fungal disease caused by Guignardia bidwellii; favoured by warm, humid weather and vine stress. :contentReference[oaicite:2]{index=2}
Black Rot.Symptoms: Brown circular leaf spots, black ‘mummies’ of berries, fruit shrivelling and hardening; shoots and tendrils may also be infected. :contentReference[oaicite:3]{index=3}
Precautions: Remove and destroy mummified berries and infected canes during dormant season.
Choose resistant cultivars, maintain good canopy airflow.
Avoid overhead irrigation and control humidity around the vine.

Chemical: Apply preventive fungicides (e.g., sterol biosynthesis inhibitors) during susceptible stages. :contentReference[oaicite:4]{index=4}
Use contact fungicides immediately following rainfall when conditions favour infection.
Organic: Use sulphur or copper-based organic treatments in combination with canopy management.
Improve vine health via balanced nutrition to reduce susceptibility.

Downy Mildew.Cause: Oomycete/fungal-type pathogen that attacks grape leaves, berries and shoots under cool, moist conditions; humidity and leaf wetness are key risk factors. :contentReference[oaicite:5]{index=5}
Downy Mildew.Symptoms: Yellowish ‘oil-spots’ on upper leaf surface, greyish mould growth on underside of leaves; later leaves drop, berries may crack or are lost. :contentReference[oaicite:6]{index=6}
Precautions: Ensure good drainage and avoid irrigation late in the day so leaves dry before night.
Maintain open canopy and remove excess foliage to reduce humidity.
Apply protectant sprays when conditions forecast heavy dew or rain.

Chemical: Use systemic and protectant fungicides timed for bud-break and early leaf stage.
Repeat applications at intervals under extended wet weather.
Organic: Use biocontrols such as Bacillus or Trichoderma species sprays.
Apply potassium bicarbonate or plant-based oils early as preventive measures.

ESCA.Cause: Complex trunk and wood disease in vines, caused by fungi such as Phaeomoniella chlamydospora and Phaeoacremonium aleophilum; stressed vines or improper pruning wounds increase susceptibility. :contentReference[oaicite:9]{index=9}
ESCA.Symptoms: Tiger-striping of leaves (yellow/brown bands), black streaks in wood, shoot die-back, shrivelled fruit; gradual vineyard decline. :contentReference[oaicite:10]{index=10}
Precautions: Prune only in dry weather and seal pruning wounds promptly.
Disinfect pruning tools between vines, avoid over-watering and excessive nitrogen.
Use resistant rootstocks and avoid stressing vines during hot periods.

Chemical: Apply fungicidal trunk pastes at pruning wounds containing tebuconazole or carbendazim.
Apply systemic fungicides during early growth when risk is detected.
Organic: Use biological inoculants (e.g., Trichoderma harzianum) on wounds.
Improve soil health and compost application to enhance vine resistance.
Remove and burn heavily infected vines to reduce inoculum.

Healthy.Cause: No infection, pest or deficiency detected — vine is growing under favourable conditions.
Healthy.Symptoms: Uniform green foliage, no leaf spots or berry damage, good shoot growth and bunch set.
Precautions: Maintain balanced irrigation and nutrient schedule.
Inspect regularly for early signs of stress or disease.
Keep tools and surrounding area clean to prevent introduction of pathogens.

Chemical: No specific treatment required; maintain preventive fungicide programs if climate risk is high.
Organic: Apply mulch or compost to improve soil health, periodic neem oil sprays as preventive protection.
Ensure good canopy ventilation and avoid dense foliage build-up.

Leaf Blight.Cause: Fungal disease (e.g., Alternaria alternata) causing necrotic leaf lesions and can lead to defoliation when conditions are warm and humid. :contentReference[oaicite:12]{index=12}
Leaf Blight.Symptoms: Yellowish spots along leaf margins that enlarge into brown patches with concentric rings; severe infection causes drying and defoliation of leaves. :contentReference[oaicite:13]{index=13}
Precautions: Ensure proper canopy spacing, good ventilation and avoid leaf wetness overnight.
Remove and destroy infected leaves and berries to reduce inoculum.
Apply protectant sprays when weather favours infection.

Chemical: Spray fungicides such as mancozeb, ziram, or Topsin-M during onset of lesions. :contentReference[oaicite:14]{index=14}
Alternate systemic and contact fungicides to combat resistance.
Organic: Use biological fungicides and neem or garlic-based sprays.
Maintain proper nutrition and avoid over-fertilization which can predispose vines.

Powdery Mildew.Cause: Fungal disease caused by species such as Erysiphe necator (and related Oidium species) thriving in warm, dry conditions with high humidity and poor air circulation. :contentReference[oaicite:16]{index=16}
Powdery Mildew.Symptoms: White powdery fungal growth on leaf and stem surfaces; leaves may distort, turn brown and drop; fruit may be affected, reducing quality. :contentReference[oaicite:17]{index=17}
Precautions: Ensure airflow and sunlight penetration, avoid dense canopy.
Apply fungicide pre-emptively when weather is favourable for infection.
Avoid excessive nitrogen which encourages lush growth prone to infection.

Chemical: Apply systemic or contact fungicides such as tebuconazole or difenoconazole at early signs.
Use wettable sulphur as a preventive in organic systems.
Organic: Apply sulphur dusting or biocontrols, use bicarbonate-based sprays, maintain canopy hygiene and reduce leaf wetness.
